md: Are you interested in a comprehensive guide to learning DBT, but don't want to go through a *$3,000-$7,000 class*, or bother with reading through Google Searches? Check out our first 5-minute video as an introduction to how our Programs work, what they cost, and how you can get the most out of them.
title: Introduction to DBT Programs

weeks.md: This **Program** only has 1 week, and 1 day in it. It is informational as to the structure of **DBT Programs**, but does not actually go into DBT Content. Skip this Program if you want to start learning DBT.
weeks.title: A quick guide on using Programs

days.md: Today's lesson is more of a preview on how our Programs work and to get you familiar with how to navigate the interface.
days.title: How our Programs Work

steps.title: What are DBT Programs?
steps.md:
**DBT Programs** are a series of *videos* accompanied by *short reading* material done *several times a week*. Each program will focus on a limited number of topics in order to help you dive deep enough become more competent, but not so deep that you get lost.

We recognize that learning is best done in short organized bursts over longer periods of time. For this reason, we suggest you *stick to the weekly schedule*, and try to do no more than one lesson per day. Some weeks may have you doing 6 more compacted lessons, whereas others will be as little as 3. We know that life can get in the way of a routine, so feel free to pause and continue your lesson any time, day or night. All you need is an internet connection and a subscription.

The rest of the exercises in this Program are more informational, so feel free to skip them if you just want to learn DBT!

steps.title: How to Navigate Programs
steps.shortDescription: Step-by-step guide if you get stuck
steps.md:
When you first open the **Programs Section**, you will see a bunch of programs you can choose from. The basic layout of a Program is as follows:

##### Program
- Weeks in Program
- Lessons in Week
- Exercises in Lesson

Once you start a lesson, you will need to go through all of the exercises to complete the lesson. If the app exits (crash, phone call, run out of battery, etc), you will be asked to continue your progress the next time you open up the Programs section.

Once you finish all exercises, you now have the chance to save your entry. Currently, all posts are private, and all photos are only saved on your device (not uploaded to our server). What you add here is for your own use. You can leave these blank, or use them just as a way to check in with yourself.

Once you save, you will be brought back to the Programs first section. By tapping the icon at the top right of the screen, you can review your progress and purchased subscriptions anytime you want.

md:
If this is your very first time doing DBT, or you are just fairly new to it, here is a good place to start. Do all of the *6-Week Intro Programs* before you move onto the next ones, as each 6-week program will go over [Mindfulness](Popups/mindfulness) and one other category of skills.

#### Program Goals:
- The first two weeks will focus on becoming more *self-aware* and *mindful* of yourself.
- The next four weeks, we will work on [Communication Skills](Popups/communication) which involve being more effective in our interactions with others.
title: 6-Week Intro Program 1

weeks.md:
One the the common problems we all have is judging before we have enough information. For this reason, our first two skills to learn in **DBT** are *Observe* and *Describe*.

#### Weekly Goals:
- Practice 2 **Mindfulness** skills
	- *Observe*
	- *Describe*
- Increasing your current capacity for mindfulness via exercise.
weeks.title: Observing and Describing

days.md: Today we will be practicing observing multiple things using our five senses. The key to observing is noticing things without putting words to them (which is what we will do in tomorrow's lesson).
days.title: Taking your mind out of the equation

steps.title: Observing isn't verbal
steps.shortDescription: Learn what it is, and what it isn't
steps.md:
No matter what you are doing consciously, your brain is executing, like a super computer, numerous programs on an ongoing loop. You are unaware of nearly all of what your brain is doing, and most of us live our lives as if our perceptions and interpretations accurately represent reality. Though professionals from all fields have tried to create accurate models of the human brain, there is no fully acceptable model that accounts for all of our intricacies. Nevertheless, we have created certain models that at the very least are *effective* in granting us more control over our circumstances in regard to the brain.

One of the common assumptions in DBT is that there is a difference between:
1. The physical world
2. Our **Observation** of the physical world
3. Our interpretations of the Observation

The physical world of a baby may consist mainly of a few rooms, people, windows, etc. The baby does not notice most of this most of the time. They are only able to observe so much at a time. And then they are disturbed by hunger, or a loud noise, or a wave of drowsiness. And then when they wake up again, they are able to observe faces, sounds, etc.  Over time, their brain is able to add more and more to their mental model of the world, and eventually themselves.

In fact, for several months, there are very few interpretations being made. So much is new! Fast-forward to adulthood, and the same baby who looked at the world with wonder is spending nearly all of their day observing very little. The brain has automated nearly everything that happens each day. Everything is easy. Everything is known. Everything has a name. And why not? It's comfortable, and once we are efficient, we can be productive and accomplish our goals!

Sometimes it's not that simple. Sometimes we forget to observe. Sometimes, we think we know everything (or at least we know enough to not need to pay attention). And then we become complacent and miss the most obvious of things.

Ever notice how most animals are content? They don't get depressed or beat themselves up. All they need is some good food, water, warmth, exercise, and a friend to spend time with. They don't worry about the future. They don't dwell on the past. In some ways, this is the blessing, and the curse of mankind. You are like an animal because you are an animal. And you are more too. 

Animals are content partially because they can observe without worrying beyond their immediate circumstances. You too will need to practice this skill: **Observe**.

steps.title: Take a look around
steps.md:
Take a look around the room you're in. You might notice people, objects, lights, shadows, textures, or more. Try to *keep your mind on what your eyes can see*. Observe and become more aware of your surroundings. Notice if anything is moving, as subtle as that may be.

Take a *deep* breath in. Notice how that makes your body feel.

If you catch yourself thinking or talking to yourself in your head, try to focus just on observing. Imagine yourself as a baby, one who doesn't have words or memories of what the objects in your field of vision are. Observe without putting words to what you see.

Spend 2-5 minutes just observing without thought. And when you notice yourself thinking, or trying to interpret what you see, or becoming distracted, just slowly shift your attention back towards what you can observe with your eyes.
